Article.ArticleTitle: Association between air pollutants and birth defects in Xiamen, China.

AbstractText: To explore the relationship between common air pollution and common birth defects, and to provide reference for the prevention of birth defects.

We conducted a case-control study in Xiamen, a city in southeastern China from 2019 to 2020. Logistics regression was used to analyze the relationship between sulfur dioxide(SO<sub>2</sub>), fine particulate matter 2.5(PM<sub>2.5</sub>), nitrogen dioxide(NO<sub>2</sub>), ozone(O<sub>3</sub>), carbon monoxide(CO) and the occurrence of common birth defects such as congenital heart disease, facial cleft, and finger deformity.
SO<sub>2</sub> significantly increased the risk of birth defects such as congenital heart disease, cleft lip and/or cleft palate, and ear deformity in the first and second months of pregnancy.
Exposure to common air pollutants increases the risk of birth defects, and SO<sub>2</sub> significantly affects the occurrence of birth defects in the first two months of pregnancy.
